newsitem.title: USA: Coastal's Wyatt sees widening futures probe.
newsitem.headline: Coastal's Wyatt sees widening futures probe.

text.p: Coastal Corp Chairman Oscar Wyatt, set to step down from that position on July 15, said federal investigators have likely widened a probe of futures trading irregularities at several energy firms following Coastal's firing of three traders in February.
Wyatt said Coastal fired its traders because they "stepped in front" of the company in trading futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange (NYMEX).
"You will ultimately see several other companies that have suffered at the hands of the same groups," he told reporters after the company's annual meeting.
Wyatt stopped short of alleging the traders were front-running, or buying and selling futures contracts ahead of a trade by the company and making profits on the spread.
NYMEX, federal regulators and the FBI have opened investigations into alleged diversion of millions of dollars in Coastal trading profits, the Wall Street Letter newsletter reported in March.
On January 27, Coastal said it had initiated an internal investigation into possible violations of corporate policy.
But Wyatt said the probe has moved well beyond the initial focus on Coastal. "This thing will result in a long story, and ours will be one of the little things when this is all over," he said.
Coastal executives said any trading losses resulting from the irregularities would be immaterial to the company's earnings.
A NYMEX spokeswoman said the exchange had no comment Thursday.
